comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -29,6 +29,7 @@ What's New
 
 - Support for Windows platform
 - Documentation restructured supporting different platforms
+- Support for static libraries
comment.body: Why plural ("libraries")? What about "Enable statically linkable oqsprovider"?

pull_request.title: Add a line to `RELEASE.md` to highlight the support for static libraries
pull_request.body:
https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/pull/201 has been merged, but the `RELEASE.md` file has not been updated to reflect the new changes.

<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -143,7 +143,8 @@ jobs:
           command: |
              git clone --depth 1 --branch main https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs.git &&
              export LIBOQS_INSTALLPATH=$(pwd)/.local && cd liboqs && mkdir _build && cd _build &&
-             cmake -GNinja -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=$LIBOQS_INSTALLPATH << parameters.CMAKE_ARGS >> .. && ninja install &&
+             export OPENSSL_INSTALL="$(brew --prefix openssl@3.1 || echo "")"
comment.body: shouldn't this read "<< parameters.OPENSSL_PREINSTALL >>" instead of the hardcoded "openssl@3.1"?

pull_request.title: Use OpenSSL 3 if available to build liboqs on CircleCI/macOS.
pull_request.body:
This commit adds the `OPENSSL_ROOT_DIR` CMake variable to the command line for building liboqs.

The value assigned to `OPENSSL_ROOT_DIR` is the path to `openssl@3.1` (i.e. the path to the directory containing `lib`, `include` among others) if exists, else an empty string.

comment.body: Why not? Would you be OK to take that on (separate PR)? And run comparative measurements with the two (M1 vs aarch64) docker files? After that we would know whether it's truly worth while to keep a separate file for M1.
